title: Europe Has to Help on Russia Sanctions, Bessent Says
description: European leaders need to be willing to work with the US on sanctioning Russian oil buyers, Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent says. "It is put-up or shut-up time,” Bessent said on "Bloomberg Surveillance." (Source: Bloomberg)
content: Just wanted to finish up the president's visit to Alaska. Going into the weekend, Amara, is going to be that what you think we can accomplish this weekend? I think the president has been thinking about this a long time. He believes, as do I, that this war never would have started if he had been president and he is committed to ending the bloodshed. But not not in any cost. Not not in any cost. I think everyone has been frustrated with President Putin. We expected that he would come to the table in a more fulsome way. It looks like he may be ready to negotiate and we put secondary tariffs on Indian on the Indians for buying Russian oil. And I could see if things don't go well, then sanctions or secondary tariffs could go up. What about China? They're the main purchasers of Russian crude. Again, I'm not going to get ahead of the president, but the president is the best at creating leverage for himself. And he will make it clear to President Putin that all options are on the table so sanctions can go up or they can also be loosened. The sanctions can go up. They can be loosened. They can have a definitive life. They can go on indefinitely. You know, there is this Russian shadow fleet of ships around the world that I think we could crack down on them. But the admiral and Jonathan is the one message I would leave you with it, that President Trump is meeting with President Putin and the Europeans are in the wings carping about how he should do it, what he should do it. But the Europeans need to join us in these sanctions. They need to the Europeans need to be willing to put on these secondary sanctions. I was at the G7 meeting in Canada with President Trump, and the Europeans kept talking about Senator Graham's bill to do the secondary tariffs. And I looked at all the leaders around the table and I said, Is everyone at this table willing to put a 200% tariff, secondary tariff on China? And you know what? Everybody want to see what kind of shoes they were wearing. I imagine the Germans went very quiet, and that's been a problem for a long time. Yeah, it's put up or shut up time, but the president is creating his own leverage. We need the Europeans to come in and help create more leverage.
summary: The article discusses the President's visit to Alaska and suggests that sanctions or secondary tariffs could increase for China, the main purchasers of Russian crude. The author argues that the president is the best at creating leverage for himself and will make it clear to President Putin that all options are on the table, including increasing sanctions or decreasing them. He also urges the Europeans to join in these sanctions. The article also mentions the potential for secondary tariffs on Indian individuals for buying Russian oil.
shortSummary: President Trump urges Europe to support sanctions against Russia, potentially increasing sanctions and secondary tariffs, to create leverage for him and Putin.
argos_summary: The article discusses the president's visit to Alaska and his commitment to ending the ongoing war, emphasizing the need for negotiations with President Putin. It highlights frustrations with Putin's approach and the potential for increased sanctions on countries like India and China for purchasing Russian oil. The piece also calls for European allies to support secondary sanctions to strengthen leverage against Russia.
